title: Tuesday, 4th December 2018
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Okay, here's the choice.

Soundbuy Hello
Grouchmonkey Morning all
BE11:05am

We can start with a load of stuff on the ECJ opinion that Parliament could in theory revoke Article 50 unilaterally, which seems to be what's lifting sterling this morning.

BE11:05am

Or you can have a picture of my Christmas tree.

Gary Any further thoughts on Kier? Share price continues to fall (and below subscription price now)
11:05 am
BE11:05am

First vote wins.

IslandDweller Has to be the tree doesn't it
DutchBrat Tree
Soundbuy Tree
Finlay Morning. Tree all the way
BE11:06am

It's a landslide!

Waterloo Attorney general gave a barnstorming performance yesterday. Booming
BE11:06am

Manxish Morning each
Waterloo Is that Trumps version of an inverted yield curve?
11:07 am
BE11:07am

.... and also a tree.

Finlay I feel that this whole process has been designed so that by the time of the vote we'd accept anything just to make it all go away.
chopper bear i quite liked mike ashleys interview with skynews last night
Grouchmonkey Sorry - ECJ
BE11:07am

(Apologies for the rubbish quality of the photo, Motorola phone cameras seem to have built in obsolescence.)

BE11:08am

So anyway, Article 50 is probably unilaterally revocable according to the advocate general.

Shinshin @BE if you turn it on its side it's more like a piece of technical analysis
IslandDweller Mr Ashley normally sets my teeth on edge, but he makes a fair point that if we want to preserve high streets for social reasons we'll have to change something
red quite sorry the eu wont take it personally and will allow the uk to remain on present terms and surely they will reimburse all those which have taken costs to prepare for brexit. oh look there's a flying pig
red *sure
11:09 am
BE11:09am

Have we had the formal ruling yet? Whatever way, it'll probably say ....

IslandDweller ECJ this morning is an opinion - it's not a judgement
BE11:10am

.... "that the Court of Justice should, in its future judgment, declare that Article 50 TEU allows the unilateral revocation of the notification of the intention to withdraw from the EU, until such time as the withdrawal agreement is formally concluded.” This is subject to three conditions: “(1) the revocation has been decided upon in accordance with the Member State’s constitutional requirements, (2) is formally notified to the European Council and (3) does not involve an abusive practice.”
With respect to the first condition, the advocate general specifies: “If, as is the case in the UK, prior parliamentary authorisation is required for the notification of the intention to withdraw, it is logical that the revocation of that notification also requires parliamentary approval.” The EU27 have no say in the revocation (as opposed to an extension): “The Advocate General rejects the contention that Article 50 TEU only allows the possibility, put forward by the Commission and the Council, of a revocation following a unanimous decision of the European Council.”

Upaswellasdown morning all. Northgate pls. Also, GSK
Grouchmonkey This opinion means the WA deal will definitely fail to get through parliament as remainders will vote against it in the hope Art 50 notice gets withdrawn pending discussions on what happens next, second referendum etc.
Soundbuy A prudent stock market reporter would wait and pick up a tree in the January sales
BE11:10am

Full presser here: https://curia.euro...-12/cp180187en.pdf

red right, tho often ecj will rule in that direction of said advice
11:11 am
BE11:11am

And Citi, to tell us what it means.

Waterloo I's be happy just to forget the last two + years of Brexit. I do worry about the forces it might unleash though!
BE11:11am

If the ECJ follows the advocate general, as it often does, the UK could cancel the Article 50 process without consulting the EU27 as long as it does not ratify the withdrawal agreement. Importantly, this would require a vote and majority in Parliament. It would create a Plan B (restarting the process or ‘kicking the can to down the road’) for both anti-EU and pro-EU politicians. In the short-term, this ECJ opinion may further diminish the ability of the UK government to pressure MPs into approving the current withdrawal treaty in the meaningful vote on 11 December.

red if it were to happen, the uk somehow getting to the position of officially wanting it stay (it wont but lets humour it for a while), i wonder how many companies are going to sure the uk government for losses forked out on preparing to leave.
BE11:12am

Written before that, we have Goldman going with the Mrs Doyle theory.

red *sue
11:12 am
BE11:13am

We do not expect the current Brexit deal to pass on its first attempt in the House of Commons on 11 December. But we do expect the Brexit deal to pass on a subsequent attempt, likely in January. This would pave the way to a status quo post-Brexit transition phase, beginning in March 2019.

Manxish @red - what would they sue them for exactly? I can't see judicial review being even remotely possible either, if a second referendum dictated a change in policy
BE11:13am

Between failure and success, we do not expect much to change in the
substance of Prime Minister May’s Brexit deal. Rather, it is the political context — in particular, the intensification of tail risks — that, in our view, will eventually push a close variant of the current Brexit deal over the line in the House of Commons.

Upaswellasdown on Kier, does that mean the nil paids have negative value?
Finlay @Waterloo - amidst the bluster, he actually gave quite a bit away. For instance, a confirmation that the UK isn't leaving the ECHR, which has triggered a fair amount anti-EU feeling
BE11:14am

Here's their working.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

First, the uneasy alliance of MPs in opposition to PM May’s current Brexit deal has so far been unable to coalesce around a single, distinctive alternative.
Second, with PM May setting the agenda, it is she who has the power to use the risks in each tail of the distribution to coerce the dissenters in each wing of her party.
Third, the current Brexit deal already encompasses a wide spectrum of possible outcomes, at least in the long run. Indeed, while it may take minor modifications to create the political scope for compromise, each faction of the Brexit debate can already claim that its preferred end-state will remain in play after exit day.

IslandDweller Advocate General Ruling is not binding on ECJ - direct quote from EU press release. (Though it obviously suggests the way the wind is blowing)
red @Manxish being led to believe the uk is leaving and being told to prepare for it, then having the rug pulled. i am talking about eu companies here. some have spent millions trying to get this right.
urgeview Cant remember the last time this happened to a rights issue....last one apparently was hbos in 2008...admittedly KIE could still close above 409 today
Upaswellasdown We get Brexit all day every day. Can we have c. 45mins of stocks just five times a week?
BE11:16am

(@IslandDweller: you've said that twice now, even though I was very careful not to suggest it was.)

Manxish @red - oh i'm sure there would be losses in that hypothetical, but I question the practicalities of suing for it. The losses would be in respect of contracts with other private parties, the Govt(s) aren't party to them. Besides, I believe all the no-deal prep is specifically labelled 'guidance' by the govt, not instructions
red @Upaswellasdownbrexit will be main decider on stocks going forward fwiw.

There follows six scenarios but what you have above is the base case.

IslandDweller Typing

In our view, while FY19e annualized stated average ND/EBITDA is expected to be less than 1x post the rights issue, we believe a more cautious view of this metric could be closer to 3x. This more conservative approach adjusts for reverse factoring, JV debt and daily average net debt. We believe the £250m of net proceeds will be insufficient to fully assure all stakeholders that Kier's balance sheet is now fully repaired.

BE11:23am

Here's what that looks like.

red one certainty is that the uk will not be allowed to carry on as is. those hoping for a turnaround need to remember that. present terms is something that will not be on the table.
Grouchmonkey @red revoking Art 50 notice may suit the Brexiteers, too. Ostensibly on the basis that more time is need to renegotiate a better deal, in fact because they think it will stoke resentment amongst those who voted for Brexit and improve chances of of no deal in a second referendum

BE11:25am

Our operating profit forecasts are unchanged; our EPS forecasts from FY20e onwards are reduced by 37%, due primarily to the impact of the rights issue. Our average net debt forecasts reduce by £90m in FY19e and £190m in FY20e. We maintain our Neutral recommendation given, in our view, the high ongoing level of leverage on a more prudent view of group borrowings.

Curious And yet the article this morning saying majority of companies haven't made preparations for Brexit
red @Grouchmonkeythere is no better deal as things stand. you need to take it to hard brexit to get the eu to negotiate. that absolutely have the upperhand right now. they need to be pushed into a more uncomfortable setting, otherwise wanting more talks will lead to nothing.
11:26 am
BE11:26am

Canaccord has a different approach to skinning the cat. But also ends up with a dead cat.

BE11:26am

Clearly the balance sheet improves with a commensurate reduction in financial risk. However, after fees, a worse than previously assumed working capital outflow and confirmation of the average debt level using daily averages, the annualised benefit from the rights issue is arguably only around £90m. While the cash-outflow related to FY2019 dividends reduces significantly to around £25m, the cash outflow related to dividends bounces back to around £60m from FY2020. We expect leverage to be below 1 times in FY2020 using average debt, but clearly there remain macro and political risks related to Brexit and working capital outflows potentially being worse than we currently expect cannot be ruled out given the industry and macro backdrop.

BE11:27am

We adjust our price target after taking account of the rights issue and downgrade to a HOLD rating given the macro risks despite the obvious potential valuation upside. Our price target of 525p is driven by broadly using an adjusted average sector PE and dividend yield based on the group's wider sector peers.

Manxish @red - yes but think of the legal practicalities; what court would penalise the govt (by ruling in favour of a company's JR challenge) for changing an oft stated policy where that change was dictated by a referendum? The court would surely find there that changing the policy on the basis of the vote was a reasonable course of action
11:28 am
BE11:28am

Which is important as the 2020 yield's something like 10% now, in theory.

Finlay @Curious many companies can't make preparations without incurring significant cost - if it's even possible. Companies dealing in perishables, for instance. The cost of preparing might not be that different to the cost of no deal disruption.
BE11:28am

Management also made the point that working capital was expected to see a deterioration of around £70m as well as clarifying that average net debt using the daily average (as opposed to month ends) was around £90m worse than the £375m given for FY2018 using month end average debt; after fees and these two factors the net benefit to what we understood to be the annualised average net debt position is only around c.£90m. Management expects to report a net cash position for FY2019 and will target an annualised average net debt to EBITDA leverage ratio of less than 1 times.

BE11:29am

BE11:38am

[W]e believe that diluting medium-term growth (which was already below average) to try to recover the ground which GSK has lost in cancer (the industry’s highest growth category) is a hefty price to pay. The bulls could argue that the 2007 acquisition of Medimmune, which was also highly dilutive, sowed the seeds of the success that AstraZeneca (AZN) is now enjoying. But we opine that AZN’s organic cancer R&D back then was much stronger than GSK’s is today. Hence it would appear that, in GSK’s quest to engineer an inflection, the risk of more dilutive biotech M&A cannot be excluded.

BE11:39am

How do we value the stock? As usual, we calculate our target price (TP) via a simple average of a sum of parts (based on 2019-21e EV/EBITA multiples) and DCF. But it remains at £10/share because the downgrades to our estimates described above are offset by the expansion in the global Pharma sector’s multiples since our last update. Our new TP implies a 10x 19e P/E, a 30% discount to our global pharma sector universe. In our experience, Pharma stocks rarely trade at a wider discount than that. But we think our assumptions still adequately account for the challenges faced by the new management team to create the pipeline-driven revenue inflection that we believe is needed to transform GSK’s below-average growth profile. In our view, the current share price discounts a premium-rated Pharma business, which we believe is premature. Our 80p dividend forecast implies -33% 12m projected TSR, keeping the stock in SG’s Sell band.

Grouchmonkey I'm a lawyer and the chances of a company getting judgement against HMG for triggering Art 50 notice, or withdrawing it, or statements about the preparations companies should make, are zero.

GSK estimates Tesaro will have a mid- to high single-digit negative
percent impact on EPS in the next few years, plus GSK has the second
lowest dividend cover [after AZN] and questions were again asked during
the call yesterday about the 2019-20 dividend cover. We wonder if GSK’s
acute need to rebuild the pipeline is pushing it into deals like this, where
it pays a high premium [110%] in exchange primarily for drug[s] that may
struggle to differentiate from competitors [Zejula and a PD-1] in an area
that is not GSK’s core competence [even if it is for the new CSO].

• While the revenue impact guidance is unchanged, this is despite the elevated volatility in Oct & Nov. Given that higher volatility benefits trading activity, we might have expected a better result.
• The number of total new active clients for the period was 14,600, down by 19% y/y.
• The number of new active clients in the ESMA region during the period was 8,200, down by 30% y/y. We believe this decline underlines our concern for the ability of the business to attract new customers under the new ESMA regime, particularly given that the period was helped by high volatility.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

• In our view, the most interesting takeaway from the statement and a key support for our SELL stance is that new clients are -19% in the period and -30% y/y in the ESMA region.
• On EPS, our forecasts are 12% below consensus in FY20 (May YE) and 23% below in FY21. We see downside risk to our forecasts on customer numbers, ARPU and AUAC.
• The stock trades on a PE of 11.6x (FY19), rising to 13.1x and then to 14.1x in FY21.
The yield is 7.5% but if our forecasts are correct then this is unsustainable and will have to be revisited by the new CEO. Reiterate SELL.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

At last night’s closing price of 608.5p and before any change to our forecasts (provisionally unchanged), IG trades on 12.4x our May ’19 adjusted eps of 49.2p (PBT : £227m) and 12.3x May ’20 (PBT : £229m, eps 49.6p), with a prospective May ’19 dividend yield of 7.0% (43.2p – based on the assumption that the dividend will be held at May ‘18’s level for the next three years as cover is progressively rebuilt).

Our current fair value of 800p was originally set in January 2018 in a note entitled Bodie & Doyle. It was reaffirmed in two subsequent notes, our post-finals report Regulatory cracks appearing ? (Aug ’18), when we downgraded from Hold to Sell (prevailing price 935p), and the Q1 update First taste of the new world (Sep ’18), when we upgraded back to Hold (prevailing price 776p). This fair value was based on using a 15x multiple on a ‘recovered’ level of earnings (May ’20), a level we think is more appropriate for the slightly lower level of industry growth (mid-high single digit %) we expect in the more tightly regulated environment. As such, we think the continued weakness in the share price during the wider market sell-off in October and November, ironically a period that provided a much stronger trading backdrop for IG, was counter-intuitive. Therefore, subject to the shares opening at a price under 700p, that the derating is overdone. So, for the first time since we initiated coverage on IG Group in August 2015 (with a Sell), we upgrade to BUY.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

As anticipated, 6m EBITA reduced 6% to £36.7m (PHe £36.0m), with PBT reducing 14% to £29.2m (PHe £29.0m). In the UK (40%
FY19E EBITA), Q2 average Vehicles on Hire (VoH) has increased 13.4%
(benefiting from the TOM acquisition as well as demand for fixed term).
However, we would highlight the improving momentum (Q1 18 -6.1%,
Q2 18 -5.8%, Q3 18 -2.2%, Q4 18 +2.6% and Q1 19 +12.0%) as management’s
focus takes effect and the demand for the fixed-term hire product (19% fleet from 4%). FY19 VoH guidance has increased to ‘double-digit’ from ‘high singledigit’ and PHe 9%. Despite the VoH growth, UK rental margins fell, with the positive impact of lower depreciation rates and price rise being offset by OEM price inflation, minimum term mix and some one-off costs. EBITA was £16.2m, including vehicle disposals of £5.0m (vs £4.4m). Margin guidance is nudged slightly lower (7.5% to 8.0% from PHe 8.3%) given mix and investment, to leave our overall UK profit expectation unchanged. In Spain (60% FY19E EBITA) the trading momentum remains strong ,with Q2 average VoH rising 12.1%. This maintains the profile of ‘double-digit’ growth. Hire margins increased to 20.6% (as expected) given the positive impact of depreciation and operational gearing mitigating OEM rises and expansionary investment. EBITA £23.1m including vehicle disposals of £2m (vs £6.1m). No change to divisional guidance.

BE12:01pm

Outlook and overall guidance metrics remains unchanged. We maintain our Apr’19 PBT of £62.0m (cons £61.3m) to give EPS of 37.4p. Estimates reflect the revised depreciation (announced 22 March),
which will benefit FY19 EBITA by £17m (£13m in Spain and £4m UK & Ire),
though this is then mitigated by the longer vehicle holding period (lower nearterm disposals). In FY19, the profit of vehicle disposals will represent c15% of FY19 vs historic highs of 33%. That said, we sense some upside forecast momentum (particularly in the outer years) building post this statement.

BE12:01pm

Valuation improving visibility justifies looking at the Apr’10 PE of 8.7x, yield 5.0% and the discount to our forecast FY19 tangible net asset value of 410p. We remain positive given the potential for a material recovery in ROCE.
